items.title: Finding Country from City or State
items.body:
Hi,

I am trying to find the country of a city or state. I am getting city and state information from every various countries. The problem i am facing right now is the response is at that countries language and order is changing from country to country.

geolocator.geocode('ANKARA')
Out[8]: Location(Ankara, Çankaya, Ankara, İç Anadolu Bölgesi, 06660, Türkiye, (39.9207774, 32.854067, 0.0))

geolocator.geocode('Hamburg')
Out[12]: Location(Hamburg, Deutschland, (53.5437641, 10.0099133, 0.0))

Issue - 1: Is there a way to directly parse country?
Issue - 2: Is there a way to get English country names?

Regards,

Seckin

items.title: amenity type and name mangled together in response from Nominatim
items.body:
It appears to not be malformed on the Nominatim side: https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/details.php?osmtype=N&osmid=3052053223&class=amenity

```
from geopy.geocoders import Nominatim
import pprint

pp = pprint.PrettyPrinter(indent=4)
geolocator = Nominatim(user_agent="user_agent lalalaa", timeout=100)
response = geolocator.geocode("Gimnazjum w Tykocinie", exactly_one=False, limit=10, addressdetails=True, language="pl,en")
for reply in response:
    pp.pprint(reply.raw)
```

gives (note mangled `amenity` and `name`, into `'amenity': 'Gimnazjum w Tykocinie'`). It appears to be consistently done with schools.

items.title: build is failing according to the readme badge
addressdetails for nominatim is confusingly described
items.body:
https://geopy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/#nominatim

> If you want in Location.raw to include addressdetails such as city_district, etc set it to True

while the most important feature is that it returns address info in a structured form

> If you want in Location.raw to include address details such as house_number, city_district, postcode, etc (in a structured form) set it to True

would be IMHO better description, with original I though that it would include irrelevant detail such as city_district in the textual description (`display_name`), while I needed exactly structured form (I wanted to check whatever response actually matches request)

items.title: Increase search distance for Nominatim reverse query?
items.body:
Hello,

I am a new user. 

I am curious if there are recommendations on increasing the search distance for Nominatim's reverse query. I am have a list of latitude/longitude coordinates and I want to loop through them and obtain their associated neighborhoods (if they exist). I am using Nominatim's reverse query, and for many of the coordinates, the neighborhood value is null or empty. Is there an efficient way to obtain the ~nearest neighborhood, e.g., by increasing search distance? For empty neighborhood addresses, my current workaround has been to alter the latitude/longitude coordinates by ~.001 and resubmit, but this is very inefficient. 

Any suggestions would be helpful. Thanks in advance! 

Best,
Scott

items.title: Allow multiple components with same name on GoogleV3 Geocoder
items.body:
The Google API allows specifying multiple components of the same type for [component filtering](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/geocoding/intro#ComponentFiltering)
e.g. 

`administrative_area:VA|administrative_area:Arlington` 

However, this is currently not possible using the GoogleV3 geocoder since the method requires that components be passed in as dict.

One way to add this functionality might be to also accept a list of tuples:
```
components=[
    ('administrative_area',  'VA'),
    ('administrative_area', 'Arlington')
]
```

I can make a PR if this is within scope.

items.title: geopy ignores altitude when calculating geodesic
items.body:
```
import geopy

p1 = geopy.point.Point()
p1.latitude = 10
p1.longitude = -110

p2 = geopy.point.Point()
p2.altitude = 35
p2.latitude = 20
p2.longitude = -120
```

I'm trying to calculate distance between 2 locations. Each location has lat, lon, altitude. When calculating distance using Geopy it doesn't seem to consider the altitude: slight changes in lat, lot influence the result, small/huge change in altitude doesn't affect the resulting distance. 

```
# low alt
p1.altitude = 350 
print(geopy.distance.geodesic(p1, p2).km)
# 1541.8564339502925

# high alt
p1.altitude = 3500000 
print(geopy.distance.geodesic(p1, p2).km)
# 1541.8564339502925
```

items.title: pypi sdists are missing tests
items.body:
Hi! I'm packaging geopy for Arch Linux.
When trying to package 1.20.0 I realized, that the tests are missing from pypi's sdist source tarball.
We usually use pypi to track and build source tarballs.

I guess the MANIFEST.in doesn't state this correctly. It should be `recursive-include test/* *`.

It would be awesome, if the next source tarball on pypi would include the tests. Thanks!

items.title: Here geocoder authentication issues
items.body:
Maybe i am mistaken but the Here API wrapper inside geopy is outdated, it seems it cant support the `api_key` argument which is the current way of authenticating with the here api alongside the app_id.

for example this fail as the current class uses app_id and app_code:
```
from geopy.geocoders import Here as GeopyHere
client = GeopyHere(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY", app_id="YOUR_APP_ID")
client.geocode("Shimogyo")
```


Basically all new apps don't receive an `app_code` so they cant work with geopy's wrapper.
is it planned in a future release or a PR is welcome? 
[Here docs about the app_code stopping:](https://developer.here.com/documentation/authentication/dev_guide/index.html)

items.body:
```
  File "/home/seha/workspace/a/archer/g/getpackage/getpackage-backend/server/python_backend/backend/.env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/contrib/gis/geos/libgeos.py", line 196, in geos_version_info
    raise GEOSException('Could not parse version info string "%s"' % ver)
django.contrib.gis.geos.error.GEOSException: Could not parse version info string "3.8.0-CAPI-1.13.1 "
```

Looks like this is a typo from GEOS lib https://trac.osgeo.org/geos
But we can add a workaround from GeoPy side by adding `(\s+)?` at the end of `version_regex`

Found that GeoLake API: https://api.geolake.com/v1/geocode?api_key=my_key&zipcode=H1W%200B4 return no city atribute, here is the sample response:

`{"success":true,"latitude":45.544952,"longitude":-73.546694,"accuracyType":"zipcode","typoCorrected":false,"place":{"countryCode":"CA","countryName":"Canada","currencyCode":"CAD","tld":".ca","languages":"en-CA,fr-CA,iu"}}`

So in this case instead of having an error, the geopy library should return None or empty string!
Fix that issue by modifying line 167 of geolake.py by:

items.title: geodesic distance uses a spherical model
items.body:
I am not sure if there is a bug or is misunderstood something.
According to your documentation your offer two different methods for calculating the distance between two points (lat, lon):

- `geopy.distance.geodesic`
- `geopy.distance.great_circle`

So I just wanted to compare your methods for a spherical and a ellipsoidal earth model. On the one hand on a spherical earth model there shouldn't be a difference between two points on the equator (east and west) as well on the two points on both poles (north and south). Using your method `geopy.distance.great_circle` it behaves like my expectation.

But on the other hand using an ellipsoidial earth model there should be a difference because the earth-"height" differs from the earth-"width". So using the same assumption points for your `geopy.distance.geodesic` it returns the same distance value for the equator points aswell as for the north pole-south pole points.

To make it clear see following code fragment:

```python
from geopy.point import Point
from geopy.distance import geodesic, great_circle

# equator
p1 = Point(latitude=0, longitude=-90) # 0 0m 0s N, 90 0m 0s W
p2 = Point(latitude=0, longitude=+90) # 0 0m 0s N, 90 0m 0s E

# north-south
p3 = Point(latitude=+90, longitude=0) # 90 0m 0s N, 0 0m 0s E
p4 = Point(latitude=-90, longitude=0) # 90 0m 0s S, 0 0m 0s E

# great circle distance
gc_distance_p1_p2 = great_circle(p1, p2) # 20015.115070354455 km
gc_distance_p3_p4 = great_circle(p3, p4) # 20015.115070354455 km

print(gc_distance_p1_p2)
print(gc_distance_p3_p4)
print(gc_distance_p1_p2 == gc_distance_p3_p4) # True <--- fine

# geodesic distance
gd_distance_p1_p2 = geodesic(p1, p2) # 20003.931458625444 km
gd_distance_p3_p4 = geodesic(p3, p4) # 20003.931458625444 km

print(gd_distance_p1_p2)
print(gd_distance_p3_p4)
print(gd_distance_p1_p2 == gd_distance_p3_p4) # True <--- wrong
```

Let me try to explain it differently. According to this website https://www.space.com/17638-how-big-is-earth.html:

"[...] the equatorial circumference of Earth is about 24,901 miles (40,075 km). However, from pole-to-pole — the meridional circumference — Earth is only 24,860 miles (40,008 km) around."

So these values differ for equatorial circumference and meridional circumference.


__________

Some additional information:

- geopy version: 1.20.0
- python version: 3.6.8
- os: Linux Mint 19.1 Cinnamon

I have made a planner board on one page and people can input country data on it and then I have created a map on another page, which plots a marker on where they have selected, and that all works, but if I edit a country that doesn't update the map until I stop running the script. any suggestions would be greatly appreciated

map_obj = folium.Map(location=[53.49, -2.24], zoom_start=5)

@app.route('/my_map')

items.title: Add pandas doc section, address the rate-limiting issue
items.body:
Geocoding a pandas dataframe with a large amount of rows seems like a common request. The issue people usually face is that the services (namely Nominatim, which is considered as the "default" geocoder in the docs and code examples) start rate-limiting the requests which results in an exception being thrown.

The issue should be covered by the docs (as a separate section), explaining why the rate-limiting is applied (b/c online services have limited capacity) and how to overcome it (geocode with delays/use a different service/a selfhosted service/a paid plan).

I feel that without covering this subject in the docs we might eventually get the default geopy user_agent banned permanently on Nominatim side (see #314), which is extremely undesirable.

Perhaps along with the docs a utility class handling the rate limiting exceptions might be added (something similar to #99 / http://www.jackmaney.com/2015/01/09/geocoding-rate-limited-queue/).

Also there's a `geopandas` package, which contains a wrapper around geopy, which might be useful for pandas users: https://geopandas.readthedocs.io/en/v0.4.0/geocoding.html

Refs:
- #112 (Nominatim user-agent)
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51393049/convert-county-state-names-to-coordinates
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38031705/http-error-429-too-many-requests-by-python-geopy
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51127617/geocoderserviceerror-geopy-nominatim-in-local-server
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49640197/error-429-too-many-requests-while-geocoding-with-geopy-in-python

items.title: Ability/methodology of extending Geocoder parameters
items.body:
Some geocoding services provide very rich APIs (in terms of parameters), while geopy's geocoders usually implement just a subset of it.

We need to come up with a methodology of letting people pass arbitrary parameters if they need to, probably at a cost of possible code breakage on upgrades, as underlying API versions are getting updated in minor (not major) geopy releases, as stated in [the `semver` section of the doc][semver].

Currently in this situation I'd suggest to open a PR adding the parameters you're missing. For a quick and dirty solution, you might be okay with extending the geocoder class and overloading `geocode`/`reverse` and `_call_geocoder` methods with passing extra data via `threading.local()` (but please don't do this unless you *really* have to).

Relevant discussion: https://github.com/geopy/geopy/pull/304#discussion_r195167065
Other occurrences: #222

[semver]: https://geopy.readthedocs.io/en/1.14.0/#semver

items.title: Version 2.0 wishlist
items.body:
(This is a derivative from the roadmap #267 with the breaking-changes plans).

Public API cleanup:
- [x] ~Reorder the arguments in line with the base `Geocoder` class.~ (upd: not actually required because the `*` makes them kwargs, so the order doesn't matter).
- [x] Pull up the base defaults (i.e. `exactly_one=False` in some `reverse` methods, like GoogleV3, which is different from the base method default `exactly_one=True`). (deprecation warnings added in #295)
- [x] Cleanup kwargs: some are passed to constructor (i.e. Nominatim `view_box`), some to geocoding methods. There should be a consistency.
- [x] Remove `geopy.distance.vincenty` (deprecation warning added in #293)
- [x] `timeout=None` in geocoder calls should mean "no timeout". See #288

Public API changes:
- [ ] ~~Change Point `__str__` format to floats (the current one causes some confusion, e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/q/54507409)~~ (use `repr(point)` or `list(point)` instead)
- [x] Introduce async/await syntax (feasibility for 2.0 is still questionable)

Inner cleanup:
- [x] Perform all `isinstance` checks against `collections.abc` instead of `tuple`/`dict`.
- [ ] ~~Come up with a more uniform inner structure for geocoders (i.e. call response parsing functions the same name across all geocoders).~~ (would take a lot of time and bring nothing but better aesthetics)
- [x] Use a single `1.x` version in ReadTheDocs for all 1.x releases, and keep 2.x series doc in `stable`. (Also to not forget to set up redirects in RTD from old version to the new `1.x`).
- [x] Try to abstract away urllib from the base `Geocoder` class. See https://github.com/geopy/geopy/issues/149#issuecomment-136526143
- [x] Add tests to sdist (this would allow downstream package maintainers to run the test suite before packaging) (done in 1.x: 0f0ac3e030f13c804a7af7c0aa238f241bd4f589)
- [x] Add "no network calls" mode via pytest marks, which would disable integration tests (done in 1.x: #413)

Regarding dropping Python 2 support, I suggest to join the numpy/[pandas](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.23/install.html#plan-for-dropping-python-2-7) party and drop Python 2 support after December 31, 2018. If geopy 2.0 happens to be released before that date, it should support Python 2 as well.

After dropping Python 2 support:
- [x] Make all custom geocoder params (in initializer/geocoder calls) as kwargs ([with an `*` separating kwargs from positional args in Python 3](https://stackoverflow.com/a/14298976))
- [ ] (???) Add type annotations + mypy + `py.typed` (`exactly_one`, changing the return type, might be an issue there).

After 2.0 release:
- [x] Replace unittest with pytest completely (this would probably simplify the tests and allow to extensively use pytest fixtures and marks).
- [ ] Adopt `black` formatter

Any other ideas/wishes? Except those listed in the roadmap #267.

items.title: Specifiy results limit
items.body:
Currently, one can only specify if only one or more results should be returned using the `exactly_one` parameter. It would be nice to have the ability to specify an integer limit (ex. `count`) so that when `exactly_one` is false, no more than `count` results are returned.

This is really just to preserve resources on the geocoding server. For instance, if using Nominatim, that would set the `limit` parameter sent to it.

items.title: Roadmap
items.body:
If you have any ideas – feel free to join the discussion. This is largely based on my own vision of the project and a glimpse look at the open issues and PRs.

The reason I'm writing this up is because I'm still struggling to catch up on the open issues, so having a plan in a single list makes it simpler. Eventually this list should be converted to individual issues.

Any help here is really appreciated!

- [x] Make the project more contributing-friendly
  - [x] (#266) Replace nosetest with pytest.
  - [x] ~~Split tests to two sets: unit and integration. I suppose that this would simplify local development significantly, but it would affect most of the open PRs, so this won't be soon.~~ Considering that most of the tests for geocoders are the integration ones, I don't see much benefit from that split. #203 seems to be more viable option for improving the tests.
  - [x] ~~Deal with API keys missing in Travis builds from forks (https://github.com/geopy/geopy/pull/166#issuecomment-374197465 https://github.com/geopy/geopy/issues/74)~~ I decided to leave this as-is. See [a section in CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/geopy/geopy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#geocoder-credentials)
  - [x] ~~Raise test coverage from 75% to at least 90% and fail pipeline when coverage is lower.~~ Same as the above point. Test coverage in forks is ~65%, whereas in master it's 77%. But having 90% in forks is almost impossible due to inability to test forks with credentials.
  - [x] (#297) Require linting in the Travis build pipelines (requires reformatting a significant part of the codebase, which I'm not really into right now).
  - [x] ~~Loosen some tests (they sometimes break when geocoder services responses change)~~ I do that when they start to flicker.
  - [x] (99be6fb + 1111e49) Refine CONTRIBUTING.md with info about adding new geocoders (a checklist https://github.com/geopy/geopy/pull/246#discussion_r174676830, running tests locally, refining docs [make html](https://github.com/geopy/geopy/pull/144/files#r179877877))
- [x] (#272) Add warnings for invalid input for distance routines
- [x] (#144) Include more accurate distance computation routines (`geodesic`)
- [ ] Include faster implementation of `geodesic` (See discussion at #144)
- [x] (#291) Deal with https (add SSLContext along with ability to explicitly disable TLS verification and passing own context/CAs) https://github.com/geopy/geopy/issues/124#issuecomment-294558848 https://github.com/geopy/geopy/issues/237 https://github.com/geopy/geopy/issues/212
- [x] Try to get 0 skipped tests on Travis. Some API Keys are missing right now.
- [x] (cfc14b1 efd4388 844ae3e) Pull up docstrings. Some parameters are missing, some URLs are obsolete.
- [ ] Be consistent with exceptions (i.e. always raise an appropriate one instead of a generic GeocoderServiceError)
- [x] (#317 #315) Add an ability to rate limit requests in a simple way (and automatically retry on `429 Too Many Requests`). This is especially useful for bulk-geocoding a dataset with pandas https://stackoverflow.com/q/49640197 (See also: [geopandas](https://github.com/geopandas/geopandas)) (#99)
- [x] (#288) Add some utility method for overriding a default user agent globally for all geocoders
- [x] (#319) Nominatim-based geocoders should extend Nominatim (MapQuest)
- [ ] Document a policy on geocoders' features coverage, missing parameters (#305)
- [ ] Extend the `Location` class with some new props (like bounding box, zip code, map URL). Or, perhaps, allow geocoders to return subclasses of `Location` with extra fields?

### Would be nice to have:
- [ ] (issue #268) A summary for each geocoder class (mostly around Terms of Use).
- [ ] (I'm still reasoning about this one) Add `contrib` package with some integrations. For example, a caching wrapper for Django would be great.
- [ ] CLI for both geocoding and distance computations
- [x] (#317) Add some examples to docs for usage with pandas (which [seems to be](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/geopy) a popular topic at Stack Overflow)
- [ ] Show warnings when Terms of Use are violated (added for Nominatim in #316).

See also: breaking changes plans (for geopy 2.0): #292

items.title: Nominatim: view_box parameter for Nominatim instance only works with string-represented numerical tuple
items.body:
Hi and thanks for all your collective work on geopy. Really appreciate it and super helpful for data analytics! 

(Note, as an aside, that it's a little weird that the tuple is (longitude1, latitude1, longitude2, latitude2) instead of leading each 2-element pair within the 4-element tuple with latitude, but that seems to be [Nominatim's convention](https://github.com/openstreetmap/Nominatim/blob/81a7ea36db7d3b055acf25a36d2ea2c27af74765/test/bdd/api/search/params.feature), so it makes sense to keep it that way for the Class's parameters in geopy too - so that's not what this issue is about.)

Anyhow, the view_box parameter is a 4-element tuple of positive or negative integer or floating point data defining opposite corners of a rectangle in a 4-element python tuple(). If you use numerical data to create the tuple, you receive an error:

Setup and Call: 
```
box_tuple = tuple([180, 22, -180, -22])
geolocator = Nominatim(view_box=box_tuple)
location2 = geolocator.geocode("Peru")
```
 
Error:
```
~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/geopy/geocoders/osm.py in geocode(self, query, exactly_one, timeout, addressdetails, language, geometry)
    161         # `viewbox` apparently replaces `view_box`
    162         if self.view_box:
--> 163             params['viewbox'] = ','.join(self.view_box)
    164 
    165         if self.country_bias:

TypeError: sequence item 0: expected str instance, int found
```

If you use string data to create the tuple, no error, and the call to geocode() works as expected, resulting in a location returned that lies within the defined boundaries.

Setup and Call: 
```
box_tuple = tuple(["180", "22", "-180", "-22"])
geolocator = Nominatim(view_box=box_tuple)
location2 = geolocator.geocode("Peru")
location2
```

Output:
`Location(Perú, (-6.8699697, -75.0458515, 0.0))`

FWIW, my suggested fix would be to convert a numerical tuple to strings somehow, but I am not sure what the most efficient implementation or input handling would be, which is why I'm submitting this as an issue instead of coding an implementation.

I'm using geopy 1.11.0 with a Python 3.6.2 in a jupyter notebook.

Please let me know if I've been unclear or you need more info or have other questions. Thanks again, so much for all your work on this.

items.title: Point normalizes latitude bizarrely
items.body:
Point treats latitude periodically and thus connects the north and south
poles

~~~
>>> from geopy import Point
>>> Point(90.1, 10)
Point(-89.9, 10.0, 0.0)
~~~

This can't be considered a sensible result.  Better would be to change
latitudes outside the range [-90, 90] into nans.  Then people who
accidentally switch the order of latitude and longitude will sometimes
get a sharp poke in the eye that they've done something wrong.


items.title: Unit conversion error
items.body:
units.kilometers does not handle the feet argument properly, the issue is specifically with line 64:

> miles += feet / ft(1.)

followed by line 67:

> ret += miles * 1.609344

feet/ft(1.) is of course the number of kilometers, not miles.  So running the following test:

> Distance(feet=1).feet

1.609344

This can be fixed by changing line 64 to:

> miles += feet / ft(miles=1.)
